title: Amanda Holden makes first red carpet appearance since breaking leg
text:
Amanda Holden rocked a pair of crutches as she returned to the red carpet (Pictures: REX/PA)

Amanda Holden is not letting her broken leg get in the way of work, as she hobbled along the Pride Of Britain red carpet this evening.

Ever the trooper, the 48-year-old was joined by her Heart Breakfast co-host, Jamie Theakston, also 48, as she used a pair of crutches to get her into the event on Monday night in her first public appearance since the nasty accident.

She was looking absolutely resplendent in a black gown, with pink frills festooned on the front, as she hid her broken limb under the floor-length hem.

There’s no Holden her back (Picture: PA)

She rocked an amazing gown with those crutches (Picture: PA)

The star broke her leg last week while on holiday and despite turning up to work this morning, albeit with her leg all wrapped up, she wasn’t missing tonight’s event either.

You know, Amanda, you are allowed to take a break.

Amanda kept a big grin on her face, despite the added difficulty faced in making her way down the notoriously long red carpet.

Honestly, if it wasn’t for the crutches, and national media attention, you’d never know she was rocking a broken leg under the ensemble.

Amanda returned to work this morning (Picture: Instagram)

Last week the presenter and Britain’s Got Talent judge revealed she was playing with her daughters Alexa, 13, and Hollie, seven, in the sea when she snapped her fibula in two places, ending up in a local hospital.

It was said she lost her footing and slipped while on a Total Wipeout-style assault course in the water.

Confirming the news on Monday last week, Amanda said: ‘Sadly this is true. I suffered a nasty accident while playing in the sea with the family during our half-term holiday and subsequently broke my leg in two places.

‘I had an operation on Friday and a metal plate was fitted.’

She later elaborated to her co-host: ‘So Hollie was doing brilliantly and going round it. I walked around it and then crawled across like an old person, like across the difficult bits.

‘And then there were these three inflatable stepping stones in the middle of the sea and everyone else was running across it and I thought “oh I could do that, if kids can do it I can do it” and I did it and I made it – I was showing off Jamie – I made it across to the other side and then my leg slipped ’cause obviously its wet, like an inflatable thing in the sea, my leg slipped and it went the other way and I felt it break and I fell in to the sea and I had to swim back to the shore one-legged.’
